5.1a.definition: A global system of interconnected computer networks
A network that spans a large geographical area, such as a country or the world
The collection of all websites and web pages available through the internet
Delivered through browsers and built on web protocols like HTTP and HTTPS
A collection of related web pages under a common domain
Global infrastructure of networks and cables
The collection of websites and pages accessible via browsers

5.1b.definition: A text-based address that identifies the location of a web page or file on the internet
A rule for how data is transmitted, like HTTP or HTTPS
The part like "www" indicating web service
The unique name of the website
The category of site, like .com or .org, and optional [KEYWORD: Country Code]{e.g., .uk, .de
The specific file or page being requested
The communication rule used for secure data transfer
The web-specific part of the address
The unique name of the server
Indicates a commercial site in the UK
Points to a specific page or resource on the server

5.1c.definition: A rule for how web pages and resources are sent between a browser and a server
A secure version of HTTP that encrypts data
An older encryption method used to secure web traffic
A newer and more secure version of SSL
A security protocol for online communication
A file proving the website’s identity
An organization that checks and approves websites

5.1d.definition: A program that lets users access and interact with websites on the World Wide Web
Used to structure web page content
Controls the appearance of a webpage
Adds interactive elements to the page
Software like Chrome or Safari used to display websites
A tool like Google Search or Bing used to find websites
Lets you open multiple pages in one window
Temporarily stores page data for faster loading
Files that store settings and information

5.1e.definition: The field in the browser where the URL is typed
A system that converts domain names into IP addresses
A unique number that identifies the web server

5.1f.definition: A small file stored on a user’s device by a website
Advertising based on your browsing history and interests. Cookies enable this by tracking your activity.
A temporary cookie deleted when the browser is closed
A cookie stored on the computer’s hard drive until it expires or is deleted
